title: Tech stocks dive as ASX kept flat
text:
"WiseTech’s response to our first report follows a well-worn playbook by cherry-picking immaterial points to refute, remaining silent on major points, and taking a high moral tone about 'short-sellers'," said J Capital analyst Anne Stevenson-Yang.

"Tellingly, the company failed to provide any information on the abrupt resignation of the head of the Audit Committee, and it confirmed that, indeed, key subsidiaries with the majority of profit are not individually audited."

The company resumed trading on Monday – it quickly went into a trading halt less than an hour after J Capital's accusations surfaced last Thursday – and fell 12.3 per cent to a value of $26.30 per share before trade was paused again.

And, in terms of market capitalisation, this brought WiseTech's total losses since Thursday to $2.2 billion.

Afterpay shares were down 3.3 per cent to $28.66 after the buy-now-pay-later juggernaut responded to media reports that said the Reserve Bank was reviewing surcharging practices.

"Afterpay is not currently subject to an RBA inquiry or review process. We welcome the opportunity to engage with the RBA as part of its broad-based, periodic review of the payments industry next year," the company said in a statement.

Appen slid 4.3 per cent to see shares valued at $22, Altium retreated 1.7 per cent to $33.16, and Xero slipped 1.7 per cent to $68.70.

Advertisement

Other technology stocks to take a hit included REA Group – declining 3.2 per cent to $108.25 – and Bravura Solutions, which was down 3 per cent to $3.91.

Meanwhile, Treasury Wine Estates fell 10.8 per cent on the news that its chief executive Michael Clarke would retire in the 2021 financial year to finish the session at $16.59.

But it was not all doom and gloom for Australian shares as crucial companies performed well during the trading session.

Qantas Airways was one such stock as it defied the slide despite Credit Suisse analysts downgraded to "neutral" due to limited evidence for capacity cuts at rivals like Virgin Australia.

"We think the market is expecting large capacity cuts from Virgin that will be a significant benefit for Qantas. While we believe this is possible: (1) there is limited evidence of this, yet; (2) cuts may be smaller and take longer to materialise than expected," they said.

The analysts did not change their target price for the stock and, nevertheless, Qantas shares rose 0.2 of a percentage point to $6.54.

Resource explorer Lynas Corporation was up 2.8 per cent to $2.60 due to a good production update for the September quarter.

Property developer Stockland, which held its annual shareholder meeting in Sydney on Monday, also rose 6.5 per cent to $4.92 per share as chief executive Mark Steinert lauded a "solid start to the year".

"Our residential communities business recorded its strongest quarterly result this calendar year, finishing moderately above expectations," he said.
description: The S&P/ASX 200 Index added 2.8 points, or 0.04 of a percentage point, to end Monday's trading session at 6652.2 points.
